body: @dhalperi did you have time to take a look on the gist ? Thanks !

R: @bjchambers 

I've massaged these commits a bit for a while to make a good migration path that can be sanely reviewed. I'm very open to ideas.
(Travis failure is spurious)

R: @amitsela 

Another exciting one! :-) I'm gradually moving towards the architecture alluded to in https://s.apache.org/beam-side-inputs-1-pager. The first step has just been to add the `ViewFn` explicitly, entirely just a port from the `fromIterableInternal` method.

@amitsela , added a new test (`testUnboundedSourceCheckpointMarkWithEmptyPartitions`). The new test fails without this fix. 

Overall there are quite a few changes to KafkaIOTest.java, much larger than I expected.
While working on this I found an important problem with how I was using MockConsumer. When we seek() on a topic, it just changes topic metadata, but not what it serves. If we have 10 records, and we seek to the end, next `poll()` still returns those 10 records. It is our responsibility to feed the records correct based on partition position. Now fixed.

Because of this problem, existing checkpoint test was wrong (it passed by a fluke, the reader ignores records before the expected offset with a warning). This is also fixed now.

I've used the `Aggregator` names from `PAssert`, but it doesn't seem like I can actually use any transformation there.
I've also added an explicit flag for graceful stops, for most of the time tests should stop immediately or they will keep executing a couple of more micro-batches (streaming) and may fail when they shouldn't.
Finally, I removed all calls to close() on batch tests because they weren't really needed - generally all `close()`, `waitUntil()`, etc. should be handled by BEAM-595.
Rebased on master to resolve the conflict we had due to rename of one of the streaming tests.
The Jenkins error doesn't seem to be related, though I can't figure out exactly what it is - looks like some Google service issue ?

R: @dhalperi
Ping @kennknowles
LGTM. There's a conflict with master (presumably in javadoc). If you want another round after resolving conflicts, LMK.
Thanks, resolved conflict; confirmed compile; and merged

These timeouts don't affect KafkaIO itself in any way. This was mainly for the local runner (and to some extent Dataflow runner). There is quite a big ambiguity around 'How long should UnboundedSourceReader.advance()' wait. Ideally runner should work fine even if 'advance()' is always non-blocking.  There is minimal guidance from SDK on this.  E.g. originally I had both timeouts set to just 10 millis. It caused cpu thrashing on local runner (it kept churning through too many empty bundles, as start() often returned false). 5 seconds timeout for start() was mainly to address this problem. May be this is less of an issue now with DoFn reuse etc (cc @tgroh).

I think 5 seconds is too long too. I am open making these configurable as work around. 
From spark runner perspective, how long should 'advance()' wait ideally when there is no input?

I have now updated the commits to further improve review and git performance.
1. The first one moves without even package changes, so similarity index is 100% thus git mv detection will be perfect and review is obvious.
2. The second one renames the classes and changes the package. It also does incidentally remove methods that have nothing to do with the "reactor" state machine - continuation trigger and watermark that guarantees firing.
3. The last one is a pure add of the old files. You can do an explicit diff if you like, or trust that I did it via `git checkout` of the prior version. Since the old files are going to be deleted ASAP I felt that keeping very good history for the new files was the most important.

For both advance and start timeouts, it has to be less than the time dedicate for a read, which is less than the `batch-interval` time. 
AFAIK Spark doesn't recommend less than a 0.5 second interval, but the rest is really up to configuration. 
The Spark runner `UnboundedSource` plans to have a minimum of 200 msec for a read, and when testing locally I've set both to 100 msec.

I see. This seems pretty runner specific. It would be quite simple for KafkaIO to obey 'max_wait' hint. Please open and issue or jira to decide how we want to pass the hint from the runner to source. May be in PipelineOptions passed to `createReader()`. cc @dhalperi.

Notes to @dhalperi (if you are committing) : 
- crux of the fix is [line 932](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1071/files?diff=split#diff-2fa38a7f8d24217f1f7bde0f5c7dbb40R932) , where we set nextOffset.
- there is a small incompatibility in checkpoint mark. Offset here 'nextOffset', it used to be 'consumed offset', i.e. off by one. We don't think it will affect many and worth the simplification. The worst case when user runs new code with old snapshot is that it will miss one record from each partition.
Filed [BEAM-744](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-744)
Jenkins is passing. PTAL

I've made some additional changes to properly differentiate between blocking and detached execution. Essentially, we can't properly solve the issue until this has been solved on the Flink side.

This seems fine, keep in mind though that for streaming pipelines the SparkRunner uses [`StreamingEvaluationContext`](https://github.com/amitsela/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/translation/streaming/StreamingEvaluationContext.java) which currently doesn't support the new API at all.
For batch, your change definitely LGTM, but there is a WIP on this now so I wouldn't want to go beyond that.
WDYT ?

@dkulp I've heard that eclipse "understands" Scala better than IntelliJ, is this what's happening here ? some type inference issue ?
LGTM, but I'm really curious here 😉

For some reason, eclipse scala finds multiple "empty()" methods on the immutable List type and complains about it being ambiguous.  I couldn't figure out how to get it resolved via a cast or anything (my scala skills are very limitted, let alone the whole java<->scala interaction).   This is what I came up with that works and compiles.  It's only once per VM (static) so any performance impact should be negligible.
